TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit ProtocolReflector extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides common functionality across communication protocols for creating objects from classes that are identified as Web services.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The abstract <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector> class and its concrete derived classes create <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> objects from classes that are identified as Web services with the <xref:System.Web.Services.WebServiceAttribute> attribute. Each concrete <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector>-derived class generates <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> objects according to a specified communication protocol; <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector> provides common functionality regardless of the protocol.
An output <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> instance can be used to generate a Web Services Description Language (WSDL) document with the <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription.Write%2A> method or one of the available overloads. The <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> instance can also be used by the <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescriptionImporter> class and related classes to generate client proxy code or abstract server code.
The <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector> class uses the <xref:System.Web.Services.WebServiceBindingAttribute> to create a <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> for each binding it identifies in the Web service class. If that attribute is not present, the <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector> class creates a single binding for the entire class. For each Web service method (a method in the Web service class appearing with the <xref:System.Web.Services.WebMethodAttribute>) belonging to a binding, a class derived from <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector> generates an operation and associated messages that are added to the <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> object.
Typically, a developer uses these classes indirectly through the <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescriptionReflector> class, instead of directly invoking classes derived from <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector>.

Docs.param: The instance obtained subsequently gets populated with objects that correspond to Web Services Description Language (WSDL) entities that are reflected from the input Web service class.
Docs.summary: Gets a object for a given XML namespace and the applicable communication protocol.
Docs.returns: A object for a given XML namespace and the applicable communication protocol.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> instance obtained subsequently gets populated with objects that correspond to WSDL entities that are reflected from the input Web service class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The operation appears as a child of the `portType` element in a WSDL document. Web service methods are identified by the <xref:System.Web.Services.WebMethodAttribute>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ProtocolReflector> class creates a <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> object for each binding, with a distinct namespace, that it finds in a Web service class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A Web service class is identified by the <xref:System.Web.Services.WebServiceAttribute>.
